comments.commentBody:
If Ryan Fitzpatrick was Black and from an HBCU, they would have turned him into a wide receiver, safety or return specialist.

Where are all of the Bob Gobson's today in baseball ? There in the minor leagues playing in the outfield.

Bill Rhoden, I salute your courage, as I do Bryant Gumbel.

Please note that screening recommendations are for those who do not have an elevated risk of cancer.  before reducing screening, it is VERY important to discuss family history with your health care provider, including breast and ovarian cancer on either side of the family, as hereditary breast and ovarian cancer can be passed through either father or mother.  related cancers that may indicate elevated risk include cancers of the fallopian tubes, peritoneum, prostate and pancreas, as well as male breast cancer.  the new recommendations do NOT apply to those with a significant family history and/or a known related genetic mutation in the family.

I see no mention of a study that correlates successful breast cancer outcomes and with the frequency with which women get a mammogram.  Until I see such a study, I find the glib comments of Dr. Love and other like her to be premature and surely not a sufficient reason for changing current practice..  How would my wife distinguish the outcomes for women who have had yearly mammograms for decades (like herself) and those who might get them infrequently or for the first time?  Under any circumstances, the arrogance that Dr. Love shows in equating those who defend screening with those who think that mammograms prevent cancer (does anyone really believe this?) is disquieting.  Does she believe that all but researchers can't tell the difference between cause and correlation?

"Women should not beat themselves up for not getting an annual mammogram. And you should know, annual gyn exams also are no longer recommended. Most women can go every three years or less, depending on your age and history, according to guidelines."
TPP -- Correction!, Annual gyn exams are still recommended -- quite actively, in fact. What is no longer recommended is an annual PAP SMEAR (now, every two-three years for low risk women). So even if your cervix does not need attention yearly, does not mean you should neglect the rest of your body! Please be careful with your dissemination of medical advice!

I disagree with the findings of the research team that having a mamogram is not useful. To illustrate this, I will cite two cases. one person survived the other didn't. The first person was my mother who was a nurse and believed that bi-annual mamograms were a waste of time. The second person is a friend of mine. You may have noted I used the past tense when referring to my mother and the present tense when referring to my friend. One morning my mother was putting on deodorant and found a lump under her armpit. Her doctor sent her for a mamogram and CAT scan. The results were that they found it was too late as the cancer was metastatic and had spread via the lymphatic system throughout her body. Her oncologist said, 'if only you had come to me six months earlier we may have been able to do something'. She died dreadfully six months later.The second lady had her bi-annual mamogran and they found a cancer the size of a grain of rice. She had radiation and chemotherapy treatment and now two years later she is fine. In Australia it is recommended that we have a breast screen (mamogram) every two years from age fifty. Remembering how my mother died, I do this religiously. Our system here is set up so that every two years we receive a reminder  to let us know that our screening is due. It is only unimportant to those who have never had breast cancer. However, no-one is immune. I have also been told that you are not likely to get breast cancer if you have had children and breast fed, but this is not true either, as a friend of mine had 14 children and believed this protected her so that she didn't have to bother with mamograms. It didn't protect her and she never even survived to the end of the treatment. I leave all of you ladies out there to judge for yourselves whether it is worthwhile or not to have a mamogram. I know what my decision is.

This, along with the recent recommendations on Prostate screenings, illustrate the need for good science and independent recommendations based on hard data. Our entire health care system, or more specifically our ability to afford good medicine, will depend on how we respond.

While Komen's carpet-bombing of the world with Pink appears to have convinced millions of people that they must undergo mammograms whether called for or not - the low-rent hyper-marketing (quantity for the sake of what, who knows) has clearly now turned off legions, and may over time perhaps even push us in the opposite direction.
Further, I cannot fathom the additional stress heaped upon all people fighting Cancer in October, who can find no peace or escape in any corner of this country from this grating hucksterism. Just a few moments ago on the TV show Extra some character named "Dr. Gadget" appeared with the show's host to promote a pink firesafe lockbox from Century Safe to "raise awareness." Clearly this has nothing to do with finding a cure for Breast Cancer, or with educating anyone about what is truly appropriate in terms of care or screening. Is there no product with which the Pinkwashers won't align?

One of the best reviews of the use and status of mammography I've read, including the medical literature.
Congratulations!
My doctor doesn't seem to have gotten the memo.  Is this typical?

What took so long for this info to go mainstream?  I've been reading the same stats for years and Samuel Epstein, MD has been front and center with it as have many other scientists and clinicians who have been paying attention.  I've sent the info to women friends for 20 years now and been dismissed for as long. Mammograms have been cash cows. Maybe they are no longer profitable so its safe to let the truth out? Not mentioned: radiation is cumulative and carcinogenic. How many cancers are caused by this toxic device?

I have a mammogram and sonogram every year and have thus far been lucky (knock wood). My dear cousin, having had a clean mammogram found a lump in her breast three months later, which was growing aggressively. She opted for a bi-lateral mastectomy, had an excruciating year of chemotherapy and now, several years later, is cancer-free. One question that has often occurred to me is whether regular exposure to x-rays could catalyze a dormant cancer cell, precipitating a full-blown cancer.

That said, I will continue to have regular mammos and sonos. It seems foolish to bypass any testing that could lead to early detection of cancer.

To those readers who find TPP "cranky" or defensive, I can only applaud her patience and sensitivity in addressing many of the readers' individual comments.
As a licensed psychotherapist, I would urge my fellow and sister readers too quit trying to play shrink by analyzing Ms. Parker Pope's responses.

The article about mammogram screening is poorly written.  Of course women, including myself, who have relied upon this screening are going to be confused and afraid.  What is not addressed in the article is any type of coherent new guideline information. We have been offered a mishmash of quoted opinions. In addition, calcifications cannot be palpated by anyone, physician or individual.  Calcifications can only be detected by mammogram and must be removed by stereotactic biopsy or surgically.

I'm 46 and have never had a mammogram. I don't anticipate ever having one unless there's some specific reason.
The whole pink campaign has always struck me as creepy in the extreme, and the drummed up hysteria attendant to it unnerving. The absolute lack of discussion of "prevention" and the mammogram and "treatment" hype is very off-putting. There's wayyy too much money on the table to be sure everyone's motives are clean.

Anthony Horan,

Invasive adenocarciomas are always found too late? Really? My mother never checked her breasts and hardly ever had a mammogram. She found her breast tumor by herself; it was quite large and she had three positive nodes.She was 72. It was an invasive adenocarcinoma.They told me she had 50% odds of making it ten years..

She died cancer-free at 95.

You are just scaring women with these blanket pronouncements.

Always remember this. Surgeons only make their money, when they cut!
Having written that, thirteen years ago, my GP on the cusp of retirement, called to thank my family and I, for having been his patient for the past twenty five years! Shortly, before he retired, I had been seeing a much younger doctor, who noticed on an office visit, and blood test, that my pulse had been relatively high, and a blood test revealed a higher than normal TSH count, without any other symptoms. He diagnosed an overactive thyroid, put me on medication, and I begin to feel lousy. He then encouraged me to zap my thyroid with radioactive iodine treatment, and go on thyroid treatment for the rest of my life. Being cautious, I went back to the GP, who suggested that I stop the medications, and then repeat the TSH with a specific uptake test. Everything was in normal limits. Thank G-d, I still have my thyroid, and I am fine. The only regret I have, is that this GP retired because, I'm never going to see someone like him again! Moral of this story, besides nothing being better than something is ( with apologies to, Hill Street Blues) : Be careful out there!

#3-- i think storms in general have an effect! my little brother was born early during the worst hurricane my area had seen in years-- he wasn't expected for a few weeks yet. My mom swore up and down it had everything to do with the barometric pressure. I too would be interested in knowing if there is an actual correlation.

I am having a difficult time with the people who are so opposed to sperm banks. I see no reason for a lesbian to have intercourse with a man for the sole purpose of his sperm. Lesbians love women, not men. Sperm banks fill this need nicely.

Anecdotal evidence suggests to me that parents want to avoid giving birth on any holiday to allow the child to have his/her own day, rather than share it with a larger community holiday.  Did the study look into preferences?  If so, how does that affect the results?

Tavernise writes:
"The unemployment rate among black Americans was 16 percent in September, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics — nearly double the national rate"

Probably not true. The national rate (U6, including long-term unemployed and discouraged workers) is 16.2% now. So that implies the true unemployment rate for black Americans, if double the national average is over 30%.

I follow all kinds of information on what works for people who lose weight. Without a doubt, for most people who succeed, exercise is really more important than diet. I understand the point of view of people who say otherwise, and I won't say they are exactly wrong, but in my mind they are.  I have recently lost 55 pounds and believe I will keep it off, but could not without regular exercise. There is a subset of people, mostly women, for whom exercise helps little, or maybe not at all. But for most people, while mathematically calorie intake reduction may seem the bigger factor, it is much harder to keep weight off without exercise. In effect, a routine that includes regular exercise helps me control my appetite as it applies to a well-designed weight management program. You have to learn to train your own brain to make this work. It helps you subvert the "starvation reaction" that dooms most diets. It is really breaking an addiction cycle that is the result of people naturally making food a "reward." You have to tame the reward center in your brain, and exercise is a big key to this. I have also walked enough in the last 9 months to burn off about 150,000 calories -- 5.5 miles per day on average. How can that not help? That's the calories in over 40 pounds of fat.

Yoga/stretching has not only kept my back/shoulder pain at bay, it was also extermely helpful rehabbing a recent sports injury.  There are some great yoga DVD's which make it convenient & inexpensive therapy.  If you don't like the first one you try, get another one.  It took me a few before I found a few that were just right for me.  And once you learn the basics, you can even do it on your own... anywhere... anytime.  And my lung capacity has grown as an unexpected side effect. Yeah Yoga!

I think what a lot of people is missing is the cause effect relationship. Yeah there's a whole host of issues here, first and foremost that we probably shouldn't be eating highly processed foods with dubious nutritional value in the first place but that's kind of beside the point. The labeling isn't going to influence consumer behavior. Understanding that, I think it's better that the labels reflect the portion sizes people are actually eating, because right now it's just too easy to ignore the suggested serving size and think you are getting a lot less fat/calories/sodium/fill in the blank than you are because in many cases the serving sizes are ridiculous. Not so much for discrete foods like Oreos, but more for stuff like soup or muffins, where it's not really easy to eat 1/3 of it or 1/2 of it, unless you start getting out a weighing scale or a measuring cup. And why should you have to be programmed to double or triple every measure because of the absurd serving sizes? That reminds me of people who set their clocks 5 minutes ahead and then mentally add 5 everytime they look at them. The bottom line is food manufacturers are trying to bend the rules by making unhealthy food look less bad for you then it is. This has nothing to do with government parternalism or coddling of adults like a lot of people on here are asserting. It simply has to do with honesty in labeling and preventing conglomerates from playing games which I think is squarely within the responsibility of government.

When congressional leadership and chairmanships are bought with donations to the respective Congressional election Committees and paid for on an installment plan no sensible person would have confidence in the work of the congress. Pay to Play has destroyed the validity and sanctity of our government and is a violation of their oath of office.

This is the winter of our discontent. Occupy Wall Street, Republican intransigence, Democratic impotence. The people....well, the vast majority of us...have been forgotten. Politics is playing against itself, and hopefully, in the end, will lose.
